prompt:
They're probably angry because too many things have gone wrong for them that day. They probably had a rough day (or week, or month, or year!) and after holding it in all day I did something minor that they didn't like and it was the proverbial straw that broke the camel's back. I'm upset that they chose to hold in their anger and let it grow over time rather than dealing with each person or situation as it occurs. I'm sure I didn't do anything that was enough to make them so angry, but because of bad timing, they're now extra angry with me. I feel the it's unjust.

###

Someone is angry with me because I let my temper get the best of me and it's obvious I'm unhappy with something they did. When I get upset about something, I not only show it with physical emotions, but I also withdraw from the situation, making it obvious that I'm upset. They are then angry because I haven't truly spoken up about my feelings and I am not truly addressing the situation. My refusal to address the situation has just made things worse. Instead of facing the problem, I have now made another person angry due to my discomfort and outward emotions.

###

Mostly when someone has been angry with me it is because they have felt that I did not consider their feelings or that I didn't care about their feelings. Even if I have done things that mean a lot to them, if I do something that falls below their bar, they get angry. I don't like expectations being placed upon me. I don't like disappointing people either or being disappointed so I know where they may be coming from. I don't feel it's right to project onto other people, so I try not to and rather ask people what they are thinking or feeling instead of expecting something of them that they might not be promising me. I don't like people angry with me, but it happens. I hope we can talk about it so we don't end up there too often and they know where I am and I know where they are and there is not guessing being done or festering anger on either of our sides.

###

My housemate is angry with me because I have left something messy or dirty. I am resentful because their expectations for cleanliness are not the same as mine, and I think they are being too picky. I am annoyed at the things they choose to clean and the things they do not, such as the sinkful of other people's dishes that they wash and the roasting pan that they used themselves but left dirty on the counter for a week before I finally washed it.

###

Someone is most likely angry at me because I bailed on plans with them. Most likely we made plans a few days ago, and they were probably looking forward to it. I would feel really bad about cancelling plans, but either because of work (needing to work, or being tired from work) I would cancel. I'd attempt to reschedule, but they were probably frustrated since I've likely done that before to them. Their friendship matters to me, so I would feel terrible about upsetting them. After realizing they are upset, I'd likely try to make the plans work despite it being difficult or inconvenient for me, or beg them to make alternate plans with me and try to make them not be angry with me.

###

Likely they are angry because of a failure in communication. I have a tendency to say the wrong thing or behave in a way that does not fully consider others' feelings and situations. I feel unhappy and disappointed in myself or the situation, and feel a strong urge to resolve it.

###

Someone may be angry with me because I didn't do the laundry. They are angry because they can't find clean socks. I feel like they are over reacting, because they can do their own laundry so that they can have clean socks. I also feel like upset because I do truly want to help and keep up with the laundry, I just don't want it to be expected.

###

Someone is angry with me because I did not reach out to them to hang out socially. I did not respond to their texts soon enough or ignored them completely. We could not decide on plans, which resulting on not seeing each other. I feel guilty for not making time for them, or working up the courage to go see them.

###

A customer isn't happy that I'm not letting him return an item without a receipt. He's angry because he thought that he could make the return without a receipt, but he's out of luck today. I feel annoyed that he's expressing himself this way and that he expected to be able to return something without a receipt. However, loud angry idiots tend to be somewhat funny, so I'm secretly amused as well. I also pity him for having a silly attachment to material things.

###

My friend and I got into an argument about politics, during which he mischaracterized something I said. Because this happens all the time, I am usually adept at dealing with it, but on this occasion, it made me angry. As a reaction, I made a snide remark about what my friend believes, which equally mischaracterized his stance, and he became grossly offended and angry. I regret what I said, and I apologized immediately.

###

The person is most likely angry because I didn't think about that person. Not because I did something bad, but because either I failed to respond or act on a request, or I did something that negatively affected them. I missed an email request and ran into them in the hall, or I helped someone else and it made them have to wait. I would feel I let that person down, and would probably try to go above and beyond to help them in order to 'make it up to them'

###

I imagine someone might be angry with me for voicing an opinion they didn't agree with. A discussion about our feelings on a particular issue might have led me to tell them my honest opinion, but they did not feel the same way as me. I would likely be upset and feel that I wasn't allowed to have my own opinion about the matter. I would also probably feel disappointed that someone close to me would not respect my thoughts.

###

I don't think people typically get angry with me, but sometimes my productivity comes in spurts (concerning both general life things and work), so that can be frustrating when things really need to get done. I don't like when people are angry with me, and I like it best when people are transparent so that I can improve the situation sooner rather than later. Overall, I try to not make people angry and keep things at least neutral whenever I can.

###

I have had someone angry with me because I would not cosign on a car load for them. In this situation, I did not feel bad at all because I know this person to be irresponsible. This individual has already had a car repossessed and I would not want anything negative on my credit if this person decided to no uphold their end of the agreement.

###

Someone is angry with me because I spoke up, spoke in my truth, and confronted them about how they were harming me. They were angry because no one enjoys being called out and because I caused them to think about themselves in a way they didn't want to. I feel strange at first, no one enjoys making others angry. But overall, I'm proud of myself for speaking up and I recognize that their anger is their own issue, it does not belong to me.

###

I imagine that someone is angry with me because I forgot something important. I have a bad memory and that is a source for most of the conflicts I have with people. They normally don't get angry with me. I do feel bad about having a bad memory and try to correct it by writing things down when I can.

###

They must be angry with something that i did that they did not want or understand why i did so. They probably never thought to ask or even talk to me about what is making them angry. I feel that this situation could be avoided if they could come and talk to me about what they are feeling and what they want changed. Many times frustrations can be handled well if you work up the courage to talk to the person and get to know their side of things.

###

A student is angry with me because I cannot place them into the courses they have requested because the courses are either full or it's past the deadline. I feel bad that I cannot process their request and that they are stressed and upset with me. However, I also feel a little frustrated that the student is angry with me when I'm the one who is trying to help them, but the situation is out of my control. I'm going to do my best to help the student find a solution despite their continued anger towards me.

###

I'm not sure why they are angry with me and they probably haven't told me why. Somewhere along the way a miscommunication occurred or one of us did not connect with the other in the intended manner. Perhaps my intentions did not align in the same manner as how I was perceived. I feel very distraught and upset about them being mad at me. I want to fix it and reach them emotionally to reconcile. I also feel frustrated that they are clearly upset but have not come to me with their concern so that I be a part of the solution.

###

The only people that typically become agree with me are my parents on occasion. Likely i was discussing a topic with my mom and we were disagreeing. My dad would have jumped in to back up my mom, typically raising his tone. His anger is not necessarily with me, but with how my mom was being treated. I tend to react the most to harsh words from my dad, feeling sad and hurt.

###

They are most likely angry with me for not telling them there was an issue. Instead, I got quiet and wouldn't tell them that something they did/say bothered me. Understandably, they are angry with me because instead of telling them they were doing something that bothered me when they were doing it, I said nothing and waited until much later (after they asked what is wrong) to tell them what they did bothered me. I am upset about the situation because I have been trying to work on this for years, and I have gotten better, but I still make this mistake. Additionally, the person I have angered doesn't deserve to have me not be open and honest with them about my thoughts and feelings.

###

Probably I wasn't being patient enough and yell at him/her first. Sometimes when I'm in a rush, I start yelling. I know it's not good, and I'm trying to tell myself stop yelling at kids/husband when I'm under pressure.

###

They're angry with me for being controlling. I very much need to have things handled and at least somewhat in control for me to feel comfortable so day to day things probably led up to them being angry with me. I feel bad about the situation because I know it's a problem that I have but have a hard time letting go of as well. Letting go is something I actively try to work on.

###

I can imagine someone being angry with me for not meeting their expectations or doing what they want me to do. What led up to them being angry with me may be when they realized their expectations would not be met, either through understanding my behavior or if I directly communicate with them that I am not doing what they want me to do. I probably feel threatened in the situation but also confident that I have a choice, I would feel like wanting to leave the situation/walking away.

###

Someone is angry at me because I have let so much time go by without seeing them and/or calling them. I have let the stress of a busy job and juggling motherhood take over and have put our friendship on the back burner. They feel that I take their friendship for granted and that I do not make time for them. I feel awful about it but also struggle with the priorities in my life. I want to make it better but have a hard time expressing my feelings and having the energy to make time for them at this point in my life.

###

I have not completed my work in the timeline that they want. They have a certain expectation (that may or may not have been communicated to me) and I have not met it. This is always a fine balance. Because we are understaffed, it is not always possible to meet everyone deadline we are given (more often than not that deadline is not in line with the timelines we provide for the turnaround times for projects). Even though I have met the deadline my office requires, it is often that customers need a quicker turnaround. And therefore get angry when we don't met it. It is my job to please the customer and I acknowledge their frustration and accept responsibility for the delay, but I do not accept blame.

###

If someone is angry with me, I start feeling very helpless. My response to that situation would depend on if I have done something wrong that made the other person angry on me. If I am wrong, I will try my best to make the the situation right,by saying sorry or doing something. If I am not wrong, I am explain the angry person the whole situation and tell him/her not to be angry.

###

They might be frustrated at me because I did not finish the task on time or that I said something harsh to them. I do not fee great about what I did, but I will try my best to resolve the situation. Sometimes I get frustrated at someone, and I release that back on them, but then they get upset that I did that. Then we are just upset at each other, but I do want to resolve the situation and clear the air.

###

This person may be angry at me because I agreed to do something (such as coming home earlier than expected & bringing dinner or accomplishing a task) and fell through on my word. They are also probably angry at the fact that I didn't keep them posted on whether I was running late or wouldn't be able to accomplish said task. Although I'm the reason that they are angry, I feel bad and am upset with myself for them being angry with me. I don't it when people are upset with me. I'm also frustrated with myself for agreeing to do said task when I don't get much free time and I want to be able to bask in that time as much as possible.

###

If someone is angry with me, I probably dropped the ball on an assignment, or I said something that hurt them. Me missing a deadline or having a conversation with them that included a hurtful comment from me led up to that. I feel remorseful about the situation. I also want to fix it as soon as possible.

###

Someone is angry with me because I inadvertently criticized them too harshly or they are reacting to my tone of voice. I feel very tense about the situation. I also feel irritated or ready to go into verbal confrontation-mode. I am analyzing whether or not they misinterpreted what I said in order to clarify; or if I need to spend some time reflecting before apologizing.

###

My dad is angry with me because I have put off a task that needs to be taken care of in a timely manner. I'm frustrated that he is angry with me because I feel as if I can handle the situation on my own and don't need anyone helping me or prodding me along. I also feel a little insecure about the whole situation because I know he is trying to help, and I do feel bad for not taking care of the task sooner.

###

If someone is angry with me, I'd imagine it to be because of a joke I have told. I can be sarcastic and humor is very subjective. If they are angry with me, I'd try to explain my side and avoid confrontation if possible. If they are still upset, then I would remove myself from the situation as I do not want to worsen my own mood.

###

They are upset because I asked clarifying questions about why they were making a decision. I asked them those questions because I cared about them and the decisions they make that may impact them long-term. I want what is best for them, and sometimes that means asking hard questions. I let them know I support whatever decision they ultimately make, I just want to make sure they are thinking through all possible outcomes.

###

Someone would be angry with me because I did not agree with a choice they made. I could see the choice they were making was not making them happy, but they did not want to see that. This situation caused me to feel mixed emotions. I wanted to help by telling the truth but I was not pleased with the outcome after I told them what I thought.

###

They may be angry with me because they feel like I mislead them. I don't feel that I did, I think that I was very clear with what my suggestion was. I suggested that they be a leader on campus and do something a little bit differently, because they already don't adhere to the standard. They took my suggestion but didn't ask for any guidance and then were upset about leadership not understanding the change. I offered to help smooth out the situation but it was not accepted. They were just angry at me thinking it was my fault.

###

they are angry with me because I wasn't good at communicating my needs. When I get frustrated I shut down and then blow up and that is what usually leads to my spouse being angry with me. When it happens, I feel really bad about it because I usually pick a fight and can be really mean to the people I love. I also feel really grateful for the ability to forgive myself and for a spouse that is willing to love me through my shortcomings.

###

My dad is occasionally angry with me because I did not follow the career path he had in mind for me. He wanted me to go to medical school and make lots of money, instead I chose to study psychology and go a different route. I chose to major in psychology and am now about to start graduate school in clinical psychology. He is not entirely pleased but is not very angry either. He still wishes I was married with a family and was a doctor.

###

If someone is angry with me I always assume it is due to a lack of communication. Either my intention was not understood, or my action was harmful without my knowledge, or their expectation was not met, or we have different preferences/values which haven't been clearly defined, etc. I always think the best way to handle such a situation is to have a direct conversation about the issue at hand. In some cases this may require time for the emotion on either side to subside, so that we can have a reasonable and productive, loving and positive conversation. I will hopefully spend a great deal of time reflecting on what I may have done that could have been selfish, or how my actions could have been misinterpreted. I don't find it difficult to admit that I often act selfishly and without thoughtfully considering the other person's preferences, and would probably lead with some sort of an apology along these lines.

###

If someone were to be angry with me, it would most likely be my younger sister. She struggles to communicate when she wants something (items, behaviors, etc.) from others and is often upset when those unspoken expectations aren't met. For example, I could imagine her being angry that I've chosen a dress style that she doesn't like for her wedding rehearsal dinner. I typically feel initially helpless in these situations from thoughts such as "I can't seem to do anything right for her," but then feel better after guiding to resolution.

###

They are angry because I acted in a self-serving way and did not take them under consideration when I did that. My lack of accountability led to the build up of negative emotions such as anger. I feel guilt and, on some level, shame. This disrupts the image I have of myself. Which leads me to think maybe I should not project an image of myself, even though I have no models as to how to do that.

###

They are angry with me because I said something potentially insensitive without realizing it. Instead of being extra careful about my words around my friends, I said something I shouldn't have and feel guilty. My friend is angry that I offended her and wants to know why I would say what I did. I am so terribly sorry and want her to know I love her.

###

Someone might be angry with me because I did not prioritize a task that they felt was important. An example might be on a Friday, I get home from work and want to watch TV immediately and save household tasks for later. But when my partner gets home he thinks I just chose not to do them or wants him to do it. This type of situation makes me equally mad because probably by the time he gets home I'm ready to do unload the dishwasher etc. His perception of what is happening isn't the full story, and he is jumping to conclusions without asking for help first.

###

They are angry with me because I am unable to grant what they are requesting. They would like to receive a special accommodation, but I am unable to grant their request. This makes them angry because they assume I am able to allow exceptions to policies that are written. I feel a bit upset that they are angry, but understand their frustration with my answer and denial.

###

I imagine that my husband is angry with me. He feels that I have not dedicated enough time to supporting the relationship between the two of us and instead focus too much on our daughter. I can understand his feelings, but feed unsure about how to solve the problem. I love them both equally, but taking care of my daughter comes second nature whereas our relationship can sometimes take more work.

###

If someone is angry with me, it would be because I am not good at making decisions. I tend to just go with the flow and not voice my opinion on what I would prefer to do. This person might have gotten angry with me because they realize that I'm not enjoying an activity or place that they put time and effort into even though it could have been avoided. I feel bad about the situation, but will apologize and promise to act differently in the future.

###

My spouse is angry with me because I have been letting him do most of the housework lately. This happens sometimes because he helps out a lot, knowing I am busy with work and the kids. After a while I probably don't step in enough and help out myself, but let him take a large share of the work (cooking, cleaning, etc.). This time he's gotten angry over time because he feels I am taking advantage of him. It takes me some time to acknowledge this and realize what's going on, but I understand why he's angry.

###

They are angry at me because I tuned them out and did not listen to what they had to say. We were having a serious conversation and I was not responsive when they needed my advice. I feel horrible about the situation, because I know I was wrong. I wasn't purposely ignoring them, but my mind began to wonder to problems that are going on in my personal life. I am upset with myself because I pride myself on being a good friend, but I was extremely selfish in that circumstance.

###

They must be angry with me as they have a perception that I did or did not do something. The first thing I need to understand is what led to them becoming angry rather than inquisitive. I feel uneasy to know someone is angry with me but I don't know the reason. I'd first like to have a conversation to get an understanding of their position so we can rectify the situation.

###

If someone is angry with me, I would imagine it is because I did something with unintended consequences that led to a bad outcome (i.e. leaving the stove on while I am watching tv and a portion of the house is burnt now). They would be angry with me because I directly caused the problem and there is no way to retroactively fix it. I would feel horrible about the situation and upset that I have upset another person and the consequences were preventable.

###

They are probably angry with me because I forgot to do something I promised to do or forgot something they told me previously. I'm struggling a bit with my memory these days, but I'm working on it...

###

Someone is angry with me about a difficult situation at work. I think they are mad because I was snappy. I feel guilty that I was cross with them and I hope to apologize soon.

###

Someone is angry with me because I didn't come to there event. They told me about well in advance but I didn't show. They don't care about my reasons for not coming. All they care about is me not being there. That makes them upset with me.

###

My son is angry with me because I would not let him play his videogames. It took a long time for my son to get ready for school today and I told him if he did not hurry up he was not going to play his videogames when he got home from school. He ended up being tardy because of being so slow to get moving. I feel like I did the right thing by taking his videogames away in hopes that he starts hurry up.

###

They are angry with me because I was rude or mean to them, or did something they asked me not to do. I feel guilty and a bit like they are overreacting. I want desperately to convey to them that I didn't meant to hurt them, but this is difficult given my actions.

###

They are probably angry because I am being stubborn and want it to be my way and I am not listening to what they have to say or considering their perspective. I would probably be angry as well and would also be incredibly upset and crying. Even though I like having things my way it also upsets me when the other person is unhappy because of how I am.

###

This person is angry with me because I was being lazy and did not do my chores around the house. I feel annoyed because I would eventually do the cleaning. Because I am not a fan of chores, I tend to procrastinate and put it off until the very last minute which doesn't sit well with this person. This person and I are different in this aspect of our lives. I can get messy but will clean up when needed. This person cleans as they go, which is a good habit to get into and one I know I should try to copy.

###

They are angry with me because I may have seemed stand off-ish for no particular reason. What led them to be angry with me was probably because I didn't seem interested in talking with them at the time and I may had an attitude. I feel awful about the situation because I had a no reason to have an attitude towards them. This has happened before and it does not make me feel well.

###

If someone is angry with me it is because I didn't answer their emails, or messages. And I have not been able to take a time for them in a long time. I always try to take care of my friends, but sometimes I just forgot to answer the messages. I would be very sad if a friend, or family member is angry with me.

###

Someone may be angry with me because they dont want to do something. I have been asking them and wanting them to do something with me but they do not want to and I cannot understand why. They just want me to get over it but I do not want to do it without them and therefore need them to do it with me. It may be annoying that I am forcing them to do something when they would rather do something else and dont want to make me upset by not doing it but they also do not want to do the thing I am asking of them.

###

Someone is angry with me because i was bossy or pushy and didn't listen well. I was impulsive and excited and rushed in without considering others feelings or input. I feel embarrassed and disappointed in myself as i know this is something i do and have been working on. I feel badly for angering the other person. I feel anxious to make it right, whatever that means and quickly apologize.

###

If someone were mad at me, especially a co-worker, it would likely occur due to an issue over work management. If I am approaching an important project deadline and part of this project's completion is dependent on someone else, then I would be less patient than normal to receive the finished product from this co-worker. In this instance, I would remind the co-worker on a regular basis of what I need and why, both of which might annoy and upset the co-worker after some period of time. That being said, I would only do this had I set up an appropriate timeline with my co-worker which would ensure plenty of time for the work to be done well and on-time.

###

If someone is angry with me, it's probably because I did not do something they wanted me to do. Or in other words I let them down in some way. I told them I would do something and then didn't do it. I feel guilty and disappointed in myself.

###

I probably made them feel dumb or didn't do something they wanted me to do. I'm not sure how I would feel about it unless I knew why they were angry. If I felt like I was in the wrong, I would apologize. If I felt that they had no reason to be angry, I would wait until they cool off to talk about it.

###

Someone is angry with me because I did not reciprocate the level of friendship they desired from me. As we were becoming friends, they wanted to spend more time together, but I preferred to maintain a less close relationship that required less time together. I feel sad that I have disappointed and hurt this person. I want them to be happy, but I am not willing to give them what they want.

###

Somebody is angry with me due to the way I handled a situation. Rather than taking the extra time to step back and respond subjectively to a situation I responded quickly which lead to a response with less tact. I feel that I still sometimes am quick to act rather than give myself time to step away from the situation and respond later. However, this is something that I have been and continue to work on.

###

I tend to be a back-seat driver which annoys my partner. I sometimes am not able to control my expressions or comments and he has voiced his annoyance. He likely was not in the mood for criticism, we were in traffic, and I said something that made him annoyed and angry that it keeps happening. I would feel bad and apologize. And be quiet.

###

I was honest to a point that offended them. When I feel close to individuals I tend to share with them my honest opinions and thoughts about actions and provide advice whether it is sought after or not. At first I feel that they should be grateful for me sharing my honesty, Then it is followed by a terrible feeling because I have made them displeased with me.

###

If someone is angry with me, it is likely because of perceived rudeness on my part. I could have been short with them in a personal interaction or taken too long to reply to a call/text/email. Depending on the situation, I can see where the anger is justified. I often tend to end some conversations abruptly and have a history of being less than stellar with communicating.

###

Someone is probably angry with me because I made a joke that wasn't funny, or overstepped a bound. Odds are I tried to be funny, but went too far and ended up hurting someone's feelings. I feel bad about this situation. I feel guilty for not thinking through what I was going to say and sacrificing someone else's feelings for a fleeting joke. I don't handle it well, and usually apologize repeatedly and hope they can forgive me.

###

I promised something and was unable to deliver on time. Even though I had plenty of time to do what I promised, I spent it procrastinating and started the work too late to get it done by the expected deadline. For some reasons, that kind of scenario happens way too often with me. I feel like deep inside I'm afraid of success and just do wrong things to confirm that I'm not good enough.

###

Someone is probably angry with me because I wasn't clear about my thoughts and emotions which led to confusion or some kind of mishap in our communication. When I am unclear with how I feel about things I can often be unclear in my communication of feeling unclear which complicates the already complex nature of interpersonal communication. I would feel confused about the entire situation at first and then I would feel regretful and apologetic after identifying ways that I could have handled the situation differently.

###

My parents are angry with me because I am gay and am not living my life the way they taught me to. I have gradually hurt their feelings more and more as I have struggled to try to please them. I feel sad for my parents because they are suffering, but I know that it is truly not my fault that they are unhappy. I do not feel bad about myself and I know I have to be myself to be happy. They have many attachments and untrue beliefs that make them suffer.

###

Someone is angry at me because I am too structured. They are angry because I constantly asked too many questions and wanted more concrete information when there is still uncertainty. They may think that I am a little overbearing and need to calm down. I feel misunderstood because I want to make sure that everything is properly planned and things will go smoothly.

###

They are angry with me because I was honest and direct about how I felt about a situation. Maybe there was a problem in our relationship and I stated clearly my feeling and thoughts. They were offended by my directness. Although, it would make me upset that they are angry, I have to be happy and proud with standing up for myself and speaking my truth.

###

Someone is angry with me because I don't yet own a home, and am still renting, and they think that I need to get it together. They feel like the "American dream" consists of things such as home ownership. I'd like that too, but don't feel the need to rush into anything of that nature, which is why they're pissed with me. I'd rather they not be mad, but I also don't feel any pressure to "perform" for anyone or do anything because someone, other than God, would like it that way.

###

Someone is angry with me for being too involved with their life. I will try to help others achieve something that I think they can achieve regardless if they want it or not. I am always upset because I know they can do more than they think, but I have become better at recognizing when I need to back off.

###

Someone with whom I'm negotiating an agreement with at work or on whose behalf I am negotiating the agreement. We are not always able to accomplish what is requested due to various policies/restrictions. I would feel uncomfortable that they person is angry but not necessarily culpable due to the circumstances. This kind of situation arises in my type of work, and it is best not to take it personally or you will not be able to do your work to the best of your ability.

###

Someone is angry with me because I forgot to do something that I told them I would do. They became angry with me because I completely forgot that I was going to help them. I felt really guilty about the situation and I let them know that it was an honest mistake and that would try my best to not let it happen again.

###

I get angry when I feel disrespected or unheard. I tend to have a pretty big ego and believe that I've thought through most of the pitfalls of a situation, and have an analytical enough mind that works through scenarios better than most. I'm struggling right now with the idea that I wont always get what I want, or feel heard.

###

A coworker is mad at me for not being available to assist them during what they deem is an emergency situation. Unfortunately for them, I planned accordingly and will be busy when they need help. I believe that my lack of interest in their plight added to their anger. Their failure to plan is not my emergency.

###

Someone is most likely angry with me because I made them angry or they are just in a very bad mood. I most likely said something to set them off and thus that is why they are angry. This would make me angry and would make it hard for me to control my temper and not lashing back at them. There often isn't a specific reason for their anger, but I'm not perfect and do make mistakes sometimes, which they have a difficult time dealing with. I'm never thrilled to have people angry and yelling at me, but try to step back and realize that they often have more difficult lives than I do an are often trying to juggle more than they are mentally capable of. i would think that they woke up on the wrong side of the bed. i feel upset that they are lashing out on me. i guess i was they first person they saw and they had to release that energy

If I'm reaching out to a friend/family/other loved one, then I always have the impulse to share what's stressing me out, which tends to be more taxing to me than being a source of relief. So if someones is angry at me for it, then I'd totally understand where they're anger is coming from but I'd also feel at least somewhat justified in attending to my own mental health. And then another part of me knows that I'd probably feel better after reaching out to that person simply due to the humor and connection I'd experience--but my conversations with loved ones also involved talking about serious or intense topics, which can be exhausting but are also necessary for my sense of being a thoughtful, socially critical person.

###

I am sad and frustrated that he is angry with me. I think it was just a misunderstanding. I cannot help that I feel a certain way about a particular situation. He is entitled to his opinion and feelings. WHY am I not entitled to my own just because they are different from his? I do not understand why he is so angry about what I said. I was trying to be supportive and he took it the wrong way and feels that I have attacked his character.

###

I would imagine someone is angry with me because I forgot something important. When I have a lot going on I sometimes forget small details and that can make people annoyed/angry.

###

Someone might be angry with me because they disagree with my solution to a problem. It is because we see things very differently. They are not open-minded and jump to anger instead of talking things through.

###

Someone is angry at me because I didn't do something correctly or what they were expecting so my actions made inconvenienced them in a way that frustrated them. I feel embarrassed and disappointed, but also defensive and feel there's a rational reason for my actions.

###

My friend is angry with me because I failed to reconnect with them on two to three visits back to my hometown ever since I left that town and moved South about 20 years prior. I feel a sense of guilt and selfishness because no matter where my life has led me and how many new responsibilities I may have as a father and husband, I feel as if I still should be able to make time for this old friend. However, I also feel that I should not beat myself up over it entirely because many of my old friends stay connected through social media and I have chosen not to make that a part of my life. Some of my friends have noted that I don't get to see what the old gang is up to since I'm not following or friending them. When I hear that, I mostly smile to myself as that is not something I want injected into my daily life and it brings me comfort over feeling guilty on the whole.

###

I said something they did not like at the time. They were tired and had a migraine. It really bothers me that they took their "Not feeling well" out on me. They got very irate and didn't bother to revisit the situation the next day to clarify their reasoning.

###

My spouse is angry with me because I didn't pay the phone bill on time and they're tired of checking on me to make sure I'm doing this. They think it can mess up our credit by paying bills late and they are already stressed enough as it is without having to follow up on household tasks that I'm in charge of. I feel bad because I know this and really should have made sure it was paid. My spouse isn't wrong and I tell them I'll make sure it doesn't happen next time.

###

someone is angry with me for being too pragmatic and not being more sensitive to their needs or situation. i saw that their actions were not appropriate, and instead o asking them what was going on that caused them to do that, i made a judgement. I gave them the report early, they didnt review it until the night before it was due, and then made me fix it late that night. I was angry i had to stay up to fix it, and that the other person took so long to review it, without considering that maybe they were sick, or had a family emergency.

###

They are angry because I tried to get my own way. I wanted them to do something the way I think it should be done. I did not let them finish explaining why they wanted to do it a different way. They felt that I did not respect their opinion.

###

They are angry with me because I am hovering and being overly concerned and worried. They feel I worry to much about everything in general and it is irritating. I usually don't understand why they become angry because I feel like I am just showing concern. It is distressing to feel like you are helping but instead you are annoying.

###

My son is angry at me for telling him he needs to get off of his computer. He is angry because he wants to finish the game he is playing. I feel frustrated because I don't like having conflict with him and I am worried about the level of anger he exhibits about not having access to his screen.

###

He is probably angry with me, because I have said something that has frustrated him. He would believe that I believe that I am better than he is and no longer care for him, which is not the case. I fell that he is too insensitive and does not realize everything that I do on a daily basis. It hurts my feelings and I would just want to be left alone.

###

My mom is angry with me because I didn't spend time with her this weekend. I said that I would spend time with her every week and I missed this week. She is angry because I didn't keep my promise and she is lonely and was looking forward to spending time with me. I feel really bad about it but also feel like it's stressful to meet her expectations.

###

Someone could be angry with me because I tend not to sugar-coat things. When someone comes to me asking for help or advice, I listen to them and tend to give them straight answers or ask them questions to make them think more or to see things differently and sometimes people do not like that. Some people just want a response of, I'm in your corner and "you are right and you are accurate in feeling the way you're feeling" answer, but I don't always give them that. I do not like when people are angry with me, but I understand that I'm not someone that everyone can love/like.

###

My neighbor is angry with me because I parked my car in front of her house. They get angry whenever anyone parks in front of their house because it "ruins" the view from their porch. We live in a dense urban neighborhood with limited street parking. Some houses do not have off-street parking and those who live there must find a spot on the street. My opinion is that my neighbor is selfish and stubborn but I have no emotional reaction to their drama.

###

She is probably angry with me for saying something that was perceived to be unkind but was not meant that way. Often things said can be misinterpreted, especially something over a text or email message. I always feel badly when I suspect that I've made someone else feel bad, and I will always want to do what I can to remedy that. I have made this mistake in the past but in my more "grown up" years I have learned how to be much more sensitive to others' feelings.

###

They are angry at me because of miscommunication. We agreed on something, but then both interpreted it another way. I feel sad that they are angry, and I want to explain my side of the story, but it's hard for me to communicate my thoughts and feelings. When I am unable to communicate to them, they just get more angry. I feel helpless and sad.

###

They are angry at me because I have not responded to their text messages or calls, and they don't like being ignored. It bothers me that people feel like everyone should be accessible at all times. Sometimes I want to be given space and don't want to feel obligated to respond to messages right away.

###

People are angry at me a lot because of the nature of my job. I have to constantly tell people what they can or can not do because of a law, policy or process at work. I usually sympathize with those who might be upset and try to see if there is anything that I can do that would be a compromise. Sometimes that doesn't work because people want what they want. That goes for me as well. I handle "no" pretty well as long as the answer to the reason for the "no" makes sense to me.

###

Someone is angry with me because they think I made a bad decision. They think that I should have made a different decision. I feel sad that they are angry with me, but I also feel that I know what decisions are best for me. I would try to explain to them why this is the best decision for me.

###

They are angry at me because I wasn't truthful with them. Sometimes, I withhold information or don't share how I really feel because I am worried that people will be angry with me or hurt. Or I worry that it will reveal that I am inherently disorganized, not as hard working as people think I am, messy, etc. I would feel ashamed and really want them to not be hurt or upset with me.

###

I wonder why they are mad at me. I think about what I could have done. I ask them why they are angry because I cannot move on without knowing. They said I missed a deadline. I feel badly because I missed the deadline. I want to say it won't happen again. I most likely become frustrated myself and over think it.
